newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAFRICA'S NZO SAYS MERCENARY LAW TABLED THIS YEAR.
newsitem.headline: SAFRICA'S NZO SAYS MERCENARY LAW TABLED THIS YEAR.

text.p: Legislation aimed at barring unauthorised South African mercenary activities abroad is expected to be tabled in parliament before year end, foreign minister Alfred Nzo said on Thursday.
Replying to a question in parliament on the issue, Nzo said he was working with other ministries and the National Conventional Arms Control Committee to prepare the legislation.

"The Department of Foreign Affairs has, on a number of occasions, strongly expressed its concern at the activities of South African-based companies involved in activities of a para-military nature elsewhere on our continent and abroad," Nzo said.

Cabinet in April said it would rush through the legislation which will include a penalty of up to 10 years or a fine of one million rand ($225,000) for any group or individual found to be operating mercenary activities abroad, without authorisation from the government.

It said companies and individuals wanting to offer any military-related services abroad -- the best-known is Pretoria-based Executive Outcomes -- must in future seek government approval and receive the authorisation before entering into contracts.
